title: Ticket #7189: Output and error logs lost across job restarts
description:
Episode 2
Did you know that self-checkpointing jobs overwrite stderr and stdout after an
eviction/rematch, rather than appending?


later clarification
If you job uses “when_to_transfer_output = ON_EXIT_OR_EVICT” and is evicted, the
stderr and stdout get overwritten (or re-written?). I know that some jobs using
‘ON_EXIT_OR_EVICT’ may not be self-checkpointing, but for jobs that ARE, it’s
kind of absurd that stderr/stdout aren’t appended.

Added submit command erase_output_and_error_on_restart, which defaults to true. The submit command does not append to the named output and error files if they already exist on disk; it only preserves them across restarts, and only if when_to_transfer_output is set to ON_EXIT_OR_EVICT. We could work around that if we needed to, at the cost of a considerably more complicated patch.

Notes:

  • We don't have to make this the default (with a config knob for backwards compatibility); it's easy enough to set the default with a submit transform. We may even be able to set that up as a meta-knob.
  • Partly because of this (we shouldn't warn if you're over-riding a default), don't warn if erase... is false and when... isn't ON_EXIT_OR_EVICT.

Action items:

  • Come up with a better name.
  • Test what happens with a job using a shared file system.
remarks:
2019-Oct-08 17:36:34 by tlmiller:
Documentation complete. Would still like to test what happens on shared filesystems (and just document the result).

2019-Oct-16 14:16:37 by tlmiller:
Tested file transfer with the following job, by letting it get started, calling condor_vacate_job on it, and then rescheduling it. 

counter.submit
executable              = ./counter.sh
transfer_executable     = true
should_transfer_files   = true
when_to_transfer_output = on_exit_or_evict
universe                = vanilla

log                     = counter/log
output                  = counter/out
error                   = counter/err

erase_output_and_error_on_restart = FALSE

queue 1

Did the same thing to the following job, and it worked just as well. (Test was run a personal condor, not using a multihost shared file system.) 

counter-shared-fs.submit
executable              = /home/tlmiller/Work/third.condor/test/counter.sh
transfer_executable     = false
should_transfer_files   = false
universe                = vanilla

log                     = counter/log
output                  = counter/out
error                   = counter/err

erase_output_and_error_on_restart = FALSE

queue 1
